revisions.comment: Replacing redirect: Changed link from [[Lucy (Australopithecus)]] to [[Lucy (hominid)]] using [[User:BilledMammal/Move+|Move+]]
Restored revision 1317046529 by [[Special:Contributions/WikiOriginal-9|WikiOriginal-9]] ([[User talk:WikiOriginal-9|talk]]): Remove overlinking
Undid revision [[Special:Diff/1314572605|1314572605]] by [[Special:Contributions/Cooks18090|Cooks18090]] ([[User talk:Cooks18090|talk]]) not as important as the other ones in this context
Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/Edward moore1234|Edward moore1234]] ([[User talk:Edward moore1234|talk]]): Not a spelling error

not sure that these are good examples of historical narratives; given that it's controversial to what extent there was an Indian historiographical tradition and that many overview sources don't mention it, it's probably best to keep this to a short passage rather than expanding it to a separate paragraph per [[WP:MINORASPECT]]
not sure that these recently added details about attribution are essential to a concise overview
/* Evolution of the discipline */ simplify to avoid promotional language and minor details
add'l bit (with cite) on the earliest known bit of "hard"ish history in India to drive home the rarity and late date for the idea (as far as has survived)

link to early Buddhist scriptures ([[Buddhist hermeneutics]] is available if want to expand the section to talk about the analysis the Indians did get up to, but it's pretty tangential w/r/t historiography until the Chinese e.g. got ahold of it)
add'l links to Indian works and to article on Indian historiography (which can be used for additional sources that it essentially didn't exist in antiquity)
